text:
Few people remember this, but in 1994 President Clinton had a similar deal in place with North Korea. It was called the "Agreed Framework". In it Pyongyang agreed to limit their nuclear weapons program in exchange for shipments of fuel and a non-weaponize-able nuclear reactor. While there was a missile test in 1998 that triggered some re negotiations, this was a path to peace where both sides were able to sit down.

In 2002, George W. Bush, against the advice of Colin Powell, pulled us out of the deal. Fuel shipments ceased and Bush began using the "axis of evil" label for Kim Jong Il's regime. This damaged relations to the point North Korea believe the US would never honor any agreement they made at the table, understandably so.

Now, we have a Secretary of State who has had open conflict with the President. It is tough for a foreign nation to believe that Tillerson holds the President's ear anymore, and have little incentive to sitting with him to make a deal. We also have a President who has decided to pull out and ignore numerous longstanding deals and negotiations (NAFTA, The Paris Agreement, NATO, TPP, etc)

Pulling out of the Iran deal could be the final step to North Korea realizing there will never be any diplomatic relations with the US and the only response will be war.

(Source: https://www.armscontrol.org/factsheets/agreedframework)

context_meta.summary: A double-freeze deal will not be satisfying to either U.S. or North Korean leaders, but it still reduces tensions and the risk of accidental nuclear war. In the escalating crisis between the United States and North Korea, the world can no longer afford to wait for a grand bargain to emerge. In his first speech at the United Nations, U.S. President Donald Trump personally attacked North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and threatened to “totally destroy North Korea.” In response, in what is believed to be the first direct statement issued to the world under his name, Kim declared that he would “tame the mentally deranged U.S. dotard with fire.” North Korean foreign minister Ri Yong-ho suggested a hydrogen-bomb test over the Pacific Ocean as a possible countermeasure of the young dictator to Trump’s insult.
